reviewText:
TL:DR - Chess.com is the better free chess game, especially for online play.

Some things to know about this particular implementation of chess:

* Two clicks to move (one to select your piece, one to move). No drag-and-drop option, which is the biggest dealbreaker for me.
* Online play has extremely limited options for time controls (fastest is 1 minute/turn, second fastest is 10 minutes/turn).
* Computer play has no time controls and 100 difficulty levels simply labelled 1-100.
* Ad-free premium is $4.99.

I can make a case for this being a decent casual tablet game, but otherwise I would rather go onto chess.com.

reviewText:
Avoid. Avoid, avoid, avoid! You want free chess? There's several different things you can get instead of this. This is one of the worst implementations of chess I've tried. To the developer: if you have to release yet another chess program, at least make yours stand out. This one has nothing. It doesn't look very good, it has awful AI, it doesn't have normal chess clocks (fixed time per move instead), it glitches, and there are some serious very basic problems with it. Let's name a few shall we?

* It puzzles me how the AI levels were implemented for single player game. Both on level 1 and level 100 difficulty, the opponents makes moves like he was a monkey and picked the random one available. It places pieces on squares where they can be captured and in general plays terribly. For reasons I can't comprehend, it is stronger for example on level 45 difficulty, but don't expect fireworks.
* I started 2 online games and both times the board was flipped the other way. My pieces were on the top. I had white and I was moving pawns downwards. That's the weirdest thing ever... I searched for a button to flip the board to actually view it from the perspective of my pieces and I didn't find it.
* Music glitches at random moments starting to make a repeated choking noise like a stuck gramophone.
* If you lose internet connection, even while playing single player, you'll be bugged by some cryptic error messages covering your scren

On top of all these problems, it keeps annoying players with advertisements.

Why would you want to play it? Other than to farm cards or perhaps gain achievements if you're an achievement hunter. And also... Why would anyone give this positive reviews? In the field of free chess, this one is a step backwards. Not only other existing chess programs and services are better and more professional, but also they are actually free and don't annoy you with ads every time you start a new game. If this game was another genre, it wouldn't have any positive reviews, because people would just say this is just a terrible rip-off of XXX

For a free to play game, I can't say much.

reviewText:
It's chess.
On Steam.
It's free and offers single-and multiplayer locally and online.

...

Have I mentioned that it's chess?

If you really need more information to decide whether you want this game or not, here goes:

Gameplay:
Simply Chess is a turn-based strategy game with gameplay mechanics that closely emulate tactical warfare scenarios including multiple specialist units that need to be coordinated with the goal of ending the oppressive monarchist regime of the other side's king (as opposed to the benevolent, generous and generally awesome monarchist regime of our king). While the attempted targeted military assault on an enemy head of state may sound like a brutal, bloody premise, it should be mentioned that the graphics have been toned down to a degree that lets you easily forget that this game is basically about two armies trying to obliterate each other.

Sound:
There's sound. If you like classical music, you'll like the sound here. Because it's classical music. Also, no dying screams of the lowly soldiers whose hopes, dreams and future are thrown away to enable the continued decadence of their ruling class, so that's a plus. Or not, if you're actually into that sorta thing, you creepy, disturbed human being...

Characters:
The units in the game each have unique... I guess we could call it special moves. Or just moves. Let's go with directional capabilities.
Yeah, the unit types all move differently. In terms of balance, the game does a good job of evening the playing field between the two sides, even if White tends to have a systematic advantage, getting a headstart in the default mode (which one may change if one is so inclined).
Other than that the factions in the game are not all that different from each other - a stroke of genius that supposedly aims to make the player think how both sides in a war are usually just staffed by poor schmucks who get to suffer the consequences of their respective leaders' poor life decisions.
The game has strong RPG elements, such as upgradeable units (pawns can level up to become queens if the requirements are met) and... yeah, no - that's it.
I'm sure that, given enough time, the developers will get the hang of balancing the various units in the game - as of now, queens are hopelessly OP and just waiting for a nerf.

Difficulty:
The single-player AI can be adjusted from disinterested cat randomly trying to push pieces off the table" to "knows how to play chess much better than I do" up to "dear Kasparov
date:
how are there still so many difficulty levels above my skill-level".

Verdict:
It's still chess. On Steam.
And it eats up like
recommended: a few hundred megs of disc space only - go get it already."

reviewText:
This is a game with chess that is free, with integrated multiplayer.

It has ads, yes. But they can be removed for a reasonable price.

The dev team have been quick to fix bugs, and have kept in constant contact with the community. The game is plain, and could do with some improving. But it is clear that they listen, and for any issues, just approach the devs through the discussions.

On a side note, anyone complaining that this game is free, and saying that is a bad thing? You are absolute morons. It is free, and to try to use that as a negative purely on the basis of it's being free is inherently anti-consumer. You can literally test out if this game is for you, without paying a penny up front. Buy premium if you want to feel like you've bought this game. otherwise, just enjoy that it's free.

Of everything on steam, a decent, free chess game with a responsive developer is a breath of fresh air, compared to all the pay-for Slaughtering Grounds and Temper Tantrums that just want your money and don't care about quality.

Of course, this isn't the best chess game out there. but with the dev team pushing through the bugs, and their quick response time to critique, I've no doubt in my mind that this game will get better.

reviewText:
In short: Great game for new/weak/causal players to play
the game vs. the AI.

But online against other players, or for serious chess
players: forget it!

The AI isn't a very good player, but it's a pretty good fun
one if you're not a great player either.

It has 100 levels of difficulties, and tracks how many you
beat.   And it always moves quickly, which is huge plus.
Plus, being a steam game, you have the overlay and some
reasonable confidence you're not gonna get virused.  Play
really is free except for 6 second ads so of the time.  ALMOST
no vs. AI bugs!  So far, I had exactly one time out of  about 7000
moves that it got stuck and wouldn't move; and rven then, by no
means a full lockup or crash, I was able to quit the game to the
main menu no problem.)

Online play is pretty terrible.  First time I tried, no games
showed up until I got bored and quit.   Second time, my
opponent never moved, I won by default only 3 minutes
after the clock ran out, and then it didn't give me credit.
Third try, posted a game with a 1 minute limit, waiting
so long I'm bored and writing this review.  (Probably
15 or 20 minutes waiting now.)

Worse yet, online, darnn thing doesn't seem to have an approrpiate
chess clock.   Chess is supposed to be that you have so
much time PER GAME, not per turn like you in this version.

Per turn is stupid.  (But not a problem vs AI.  Against AI,
take as long as you want, and then it moves quickly.  Very
nice.)

But online, per turn clock (instead of proper per-game clock
means you either pick a long time limit, and might have
to wait way too long for early moves and end-games
where there might just be 4 or 5 piece left on the board.
Pick a short time limit, it might not be enough for the mid-game,
when you need to think things through.

Default time limit seem to be days, or sometihng like that.
Hardly reasonable.

So, if you're a very casual" player
date: it's a good game for vs.\nAI.  Try to see if you beat each of all 100 levels.   If you're a\ngood serious player
hoursPlayed: this game is probably overpriced at\nfree."

reviewText:
I've been wanting to get a Chess game on steam for a while, so this coming out is pretty much perfect! It's chess, plain and simple, plus the fact that it's free makes it better. The fact that it has steamworks is another huge plus.

That said, the game does have some issues. The biggest one is the lack of an actual resign button, meaning that if a player wishes to quit, they have to go AFK until the timer (7 days by default, but can be altered) runs out . There are also weird glitches that pop up all over, but the developers are very active on the forums and have been issuing patches daily. The worst glitch currently is that if you win by the other person running out of time, it doesn't actually log as a victory.

Problems aside though, having a mostly well-made, Steamworks enabled, and free Chess game is very nice. I'm sure the bugs will be sorted out. Also, the people whining about ads are dumb, IT'S A FREE GAME. Being free lets this have a larger playerbase than it probably would have gotten and the ads aren't even bad. Also you can pay 5 bucks to remove them.

EDIT: They have indeed added a resign button. Thanks devs!

reviewText:
Fun, addictive, and a good mental exercise. Simply Chess is a must-have.
Chess is my all time favorite boardgame. I've played it since grade school.

When I saw a F2P version of it on Steam, I had to try it out. I'm pleasantly surprised.

There's a ranked online matching system that uses ELO to determine opponents. If you don't want to play online and instead want to hone up on your gambits or sweeps, you can take the AI for a spin (the AI has a multitude of difficulty levels).

What I really like though is the amalgamation of the game. The simplicity of the classic chess board and pieces, blended with a decent game engine and relaxing classical music, provide for a very calming yet mentally stimulating experience.

I feel that a firm grasp on Chess will also provide one with carry over skills that can greatly benefit your life. It helps with memory retention, projection, strategizing, critical thinking, twitch/quick thinking, opponent/competitive psychology, sportsmanship and focus.

I definitely recommend this game and playing it at least 45mins-1hr a day (whether on Steam, or in person with an actual chess board). Add it on top of a physical exercise regimine and you will be on your way to being a highly improved and efficient human being. :D

reviewText:
Now that the runtime bug has been fixed I felt it there was a need for me to rewrite a proper review now that I can play the game.

It is as it's title says, Simply Chess. There's no interesting challenge modes or anything so don't expect anything fancy from it (Though it would be a nice twist if something of the sort was added). There is a play by turn, where you can make a move  in a game with your friend and wait for them to take their turn. There's also Local/Online multiplayer, if you're feeling competative. And of course the Vs Computer for those who hate playing against humans.

Chess alone is not the biggest deal in games as many of us know, but if you prefer a simple board game here on steam, this I recommend, even if it only entertains for a little while.

I personally might play a match or so a day, so if you happen to see me on, feel free to invite me :3

Simply bad. It does not even work on 64bit Ubuntu where it installs wrong libraries and then reports error messages about missing libraries.

Internet chess have evolved during the years, so why don't the devs check a client like Jin or Win/Xboard, and the features servers like FICS and ICS, and start from there. The matchmaking system presented in Simply Chess is horribly clunky compared to Seeks in FICS and ICS.

reviewText:
A good time waster. I am by no means a chess genius so AI level 6 seems to be about my skill level. I notice the AI has a few quirks at this level. It doesn't seem to grasp the concept that the king can defend itself in a limited fashion. It thinks it has me beat by putting it's queen next to my king. King takes queen.

It's also very protective of it's pieces. For example if there's ever a situation where it could take my rook by sacrificing a bishop it will never take my rook, even if it would put it in a better position strategically speaking. This basically allows me to control the board by purposefully putting my pieces in dangerous sitations forcing it to back off. It probably doesn't act this way at higher levels.

Other than that, it's chess and it's free. There's probably a million others out there just like it but this is the first that's made it to Steam.

reviewText:
Three Words.

Steam. Multiplayer. Chess.

Finally, a decent chess game is on Steam, and to top it off its Free to Play! Plays great so far, with only a few minimal bugs/crashes, but the developers are working as quickly as they can to improve the game/add suggestions.  There is an Upgrade to Premium option for $5.00 which removes ads, but I have really only seen ads in Single Player play against the CPU. Online Play hasn't giving me ads yet.

Its been really fun playing against other Steam users in the past few games I've played. This is a welcome treat to Steam.  Looks like this is the closest we will get to having the old Steam Parlor games from the olden days of Steam. Now all we need is a Checkers game and maybe Tic Tac Toe!

Really nice chess game, looking forward to the many improvements to come! A Must Play game for any Steam user who likes Chess.

Well, I am a chess player with 1700 elo rating and I enjoy to go chess tournaments etc. but i tested this game like an hour and i can say its worst experience i have ever done about chess! Let me explain why:
1. Online mode's timer
Online mode have timer yes, but its completely useless since timing choices going like 1 min/per move and 10 min/per move, why didnt you put 2 min 3 min etc. too? Come on, 10 min/per move match lasts 9 times more than 1 min/per move its an abyss.
Worse than that, you cant see your timer whilst playing in-game! You need to get some telephone timer and check, its stupid af.
Also this game doesnt have fischer timer clock which is extremely stupid too, maybe I want to play like just 5-45 min short match and by game's system its impossible, because you can wait 1 min for every move, so even if you playing with shortest time mode game might be take 2 hours.
I noticed that you cant use timer while playing with AI.
2. AI system
I used stockfish to develop for chess tournaments, and I know that its strong af, but come on I am 1700 elo player and I doubt if level 10 AI did mistake while playing with me, game finished draw and then I played once more time, at that game he made an obvious mistake, and I won easily, I am trying to say that its unbalanced and even can level 10 AI go crazy sometimes.
3. Music
I am %100 sure that I heard main music on another game at Kongregate, I am not trying to say gamemakers stole that but they could have used some original music for game.
In-game musics are also stupid, I know I can mute that but it had negative effect when I played for first time.
4. Boards
Even Chessmaster(which is an old game) have some cool graphics and boards, but this game not very much board option, bad graphics and you have to check them by playing a game(no inspect mode).
I have noticed that much thing in only 1 hour, this game is really awkward trust me.

reviewText:
TL:DR - Chess.com is the better free chess game, especially for online play.

Some things to know about this particular implementation of chess:

* Two clicks to move (one to select your piece, one to move). No drag-and-drop option, which is the biggest dealbreaker for me.
* Online play has extremely limited options for time controls (fastest is 1 minute/turn, second fastest is 10 minutes/turn).
* Computer play has no time controls and 100 difficulty levels simply labelled 1-100.
* Ad-free premium is $4.99.

I can make a case for this being a decent casual tablet game, but otherwise I would rather go onto chess.com.

reviewText:
Avoid. Avoid, avoid, avoid! You want free chess? There's several different things you can get instead of this. This is one of the worst implementations of chess I've tried. To the developer: if you have to release yet another chess program, at least make yours stand out. This one has nothing. It doesn't look very good, it has awful AI, it doesn't have normal chess clocks (fixed time per move instead), it glitches, and there are some serious very basic problems with it. Let's name a few shall we?

* It puzzles me how the AI levels were implemented for single player game. Both on level 1 and level 100 difficulty, the opponents makes moves like he was a monkey and picked the random one available. It places pieces on squares where they can be captured and in general plays terribly. For reasons I can't comprehend, it is stronger for example on level 45 difficulty, but don't expect fireworks.
* I started 2 online games and both times the board was flipped the other way. My pieces were on the top. I had white and I was moving pawns downwards. That's the weirdest thing ever... I searched for a button to flip the board to actually view it from the perspective of my pieces and I didn't find it.
* Music glitches at random moments starting to make a repeated choking noise like a stuck gramophone.
* If you lose internet connection, even while playing single player, you'll be bugged by some cryptic error messages covering your scren

On top of all these problems, it keeps annoying players with advertisements.

Why would you want to play it? Other than to farm cards or perhaps gain achievements if you're an achievement hunter. And also... Why would anyone give this positive reviews? In the field of free chess, this one is a step backwards. Not only other existing chess programs and services are better and more professional, but also they are actually free and don't annoy you with ads every time you start a new game. If this game was another genre, it wouldn't have any positive reviews, because people would just say this is just a terrible rip-off of XXX

As a chess fan, this isn't bad. Had a single match vs a level 1 opponent and it went well. If this is was a project someone put together, it's pretty decent.

For a free to play game, I can't say much.

The quality of the music is terrible. The music broke about 5 minutes into the match anyway so it wasn't missed.

Overall, it did what it was supposed to. However, the reason I'm not giving this a recommendation is there are much better options elsewhere. Some polish could have been put into it before pushing it out (free to play or not.)

reviewText:
It's chess.
On Steam.
It's free and offers single-and multiplayer locally and online.

...

Have I mentioned that it's chess?

If you really need more information to decide whether you want this game or not, here goes:

Gameplay:
Simply Chess is a turn-based strategy game with gameplay mechanics that closely emulate tactical warfare scenarios including multiple specialist units that need to be coordinated with the goal of ending the oppressive monarchist regime of the other side's king (as opposed to the benevolent, generous and generally awesome monarchist regime of our king). While the attempted targeted military assault on an enemy head of state may sound like a brutal, bloody premise, it should be mentioned that the graphics have been toned down to a degree that lets you easily forget that this game is basically about two armies trying to obliterate each other.

Sound:
There's sound. If you like classical music, you'll like the sound here. Because it's classical music. Also, no dying screams of the lowly soldiers whose hopes, dreams and future are thrown away to enable the continued decadence of their ruling class, so that's a plus. Or not, if you're actually into that sorta thing, you creepy, disturbed human being...

Characters:
The units in the game each have unique... I guess we could call it special moves. Or just moves. Let's go with directional capabilities.
Yeah, the unit types all move differently. In terms of balance, the game does a good job of evening the playing field between the two sides, even if White tends to have a systematic advantage, getting a headstart in the default mode (which one may change if one is so inclined).
Other than that the factions in the game are not all that different from each other - a stroke of genius that supposedly aims to make the player think how both sides in a war are usually just staffed by poor schmucks who get to suffer the consequences of their respective leaders' poor life decisions.
The game has strong RPG elements, such as upgradeable units (pawns can level up to become queens if the requirements are met) and... yeah, no - that's it.
I'm sure that, given enough time, the developers will get the hang of balancing the various units in the game - as of now, queens are hopelessly OP and just waiting for a nerf.

Difficulty:
The single-player AI can be adjusted from disinterested cat randomly trying to push pieces off the table" to "knows how to play chess much better than I do" up to "dear Kasparov
date:
how are there still so many difficulty levels above my skill-level".

Verdict:
It's still chess. On Steam.
And it eats up like
recommended: a few hundred megs of disc space only - go get it already."

reviewText:
This is a game with chess that is free, with integrated multiplayer.

It has ads, yes. But they can be removed for a reasonable price.

The dev team have been quick to fix bugs, and have kept in constant contact with the community. The game is plain, and could do with some improving. But it is clear that they listen, and for any issues, just approach the devs through the discussions.

On a side note, anyone complaining that this game is free, and saying that is a bad thing? You are absolute morons. It is free, and to try to use that as a negative purely on the basis of it's being free is inherently anti-consumer. You can literally test out if this game is for you, without paying a penny up front. Buy premium if you want to feel like you've bought this game. otherwise, just enjoy that it's free.

Of everything on steam, a decent, free chess game with a responsive developer is a breath of fresh air, compared to all the pay-for Slaughtering Grounds and Temper Tantrums that just want your money and don't care about quality.

reviewText:
In short: Great game for new/weak/causal players to play
the game vs. the AI.

But online against other players, or for serious chess
players: forget it!

The AI isn't a very good player, but it's a pretty good fun
one if you're not a great player either.

It has 100 levels of difficulties, and tracks how many you
beat.   And it always moves quickly, which is huge plus.
Plus, being a steam game, you have the overlay and some
reasonable confidence you're not gonna get virused.  Play
really is free except for 6 second ads so of the time.  ALMOST
no vs. AI bugs!  So far, I had exactly one time out of  about 7000
moves that it got stuck and wouldn't move; and rven then, by no
means a full lockup or crash, I was able to quit the game to the
main menu no problem.)

Online play is pretty terrible.  First time I tried, no games
showed up until I got bored and quit.   Second time, my
opponent never moved, I won by default only 3 minutes
after the clock ran out, and then it didn't give me credit.
Third try, posted a game with a 1 minute limit, waiting
so long I'm bored and writing this review.  (Probably
15 or 20 minutes waiting now.)

Worse yet, online, darnn thing doesn't seem to have an approrpiate
chess clock.   Chess is supposed to be that you have so
much time PER GAME, not per turn like you in this version.

Per turn is stupid.  (But not a problem vs AI.  Against AI,
take as long as you want, and then it moves quickly.  Very
nice.)

But online, per turn clock (instead of proper per-game clock
means you either pick a long time limit, and might have
to wait way too long for early moves and end-games
where there might just be 4 or 5 piece left on the board.
Pick a short time limit, it might not be enough for the mid-game,
when you need to think things through.

Default time limit seem to be days, or sometihng like that.
Hardly reasonable.

So, if you're a very casual" player
date: it's a good game for vs.\nAI.  Try to see if you beat each of all 100 levels.   If you're a\ngood serious player
hoursPlayed: this game is probably overpriced at\nfree."

reviewText:
I've been wanting to get a Chess game on steam for a while, so this coming out is pretty much perfect! It's chess, plain and simple, plus the fact that it's free makes it better. The fact that it has steamworks is another huge plus.

That said, the game does have some issues. The biggest one is the lack of an actual resign button, meaning that if a player wishes to quit, they have to go AFK until the timer (7 days by default, but can be altered) runs out . There are also weird glitches that pop up all over, but the developers are very active on the forums and have been issuing patches daily. The worst glitch currently is that if you win by the other person running out of time, it doesn't actually log as a victory.

Problems aside though, having a mostly well-made, Steamworks enabled, and free Chess game is very nice. I'm sure the bugs will be sorted out. Also, the people whining about ads are dumb, IT'S A FREE GAME. Being free lets this have a larger playerbase than it probably would have gotten and the ads aren't even bad. Also you can pay 5 bucks to remove them.

EDIT: They have indeed added a resign button. Thanks devs!

reviewText:
Fun, addictive, and a good mental exercise. Simply Chess is a must-have.
Chess is my all time favorite boardgame. I've played it since grade school.

When I saw a F2P version of it on Steam, I had to try it out. I'm pleasantly surprised.

There's a ranked online matching system that uses ELO to determine opponents. If you don't want to play online and instead want to hone up on your gambits or sweeps, you can take the AI for a spin (the AI has a multitude of difficulty levels).

What I really like though is the amalgamation of the game. The simplicity of the classic chess board and pieces, blended with a decent game engine and relaxing classical music, provide for a very calming yet mentally stimulating experience.

I feel that a firm grasp on Chess will also provide one with carry over skills that can greatly benefit your life. It helps with memory retention, projection, strategizing, critical thinking, twitch/quick thinking, opponent/competitive psychology, sportsmanship and focus.

I definitely recommend this game and playing it at least 45mins-1hr a day (whether on Steam, or in person with an actual chess board). Add it on top of a physical exercise regimine and you will be on your way to being a highly improved and efficient human being. :D

reviewText:
Now that the runtime bug has been fixed I felt it there was a need for me to rewrite a proper review now that I can play the game.

It is as it's title says, Simply Chess. There's no interesting challenge modes or anything so don't expect anything fancy from it (Though it would be a nice twist if something of the sort was added). There is a play by turn, where you can make a move  in a game with your friend and wait for them to take their turn. There's also Local/Online multiplayer, if you're feeling competative. And of course the Vs Computer for those who hate playing against humans.

Chess alone is not the biggest deal in games as many of us know, but if you prefer a simple board game here on steam, this I recommend, even if it only entertains for a little while.

I personally might play a match or so a day, so if you happen to see me on, feel free to invite me :3

Simply bad. It does not even work on 64bit Ubuntu where it installs wrong libraries and then reports error messages about missing libraries.

Internet chess have evolved during the years, so why don't the devs check a client like Jin or Win/Xboard, and the features servers like FICS and ICS, and start from there. The matchmaking system presented in Simply Chess is horribly clunky compared to Seeks in FICS and ICS.

reviewText:
As far as I can tell this is the only Chess game on steam that's free. Though it's still being updated, it has steam support. a descent AI system, online battles with a tad bit of delay but that's fine and the ability to set the board to 2D mode or 3D with a rotatable camera.

Some critisicisms though:
-The board orientation never changes depending on which side you choose, white will always be on the bottom. (Fixed)
-There is a bit of jitteriness with 3D but that might be the fault of my crap PC
-The GUI for games doesn't seem very appealing but it's ok (Fixed)
-Even though everything is recognisable, the art style is just lacking that simplistic and crispy look that I've come to enjoy in Chess games.
-Barely any different styles.
-Ads that you have to pay to get rid of
-no drag and drop (Fixed)
-no timer so people can go AFK if they know they've lost and thus forcing you to concede from impatience

At the end of the day, it's free chess, it's fine (though a bit lackluster)


oh yeah, and controller support...for some reason

reviewText:
The title says what it's supposed to say. Just chess. Nothing special.

The game features online and offline play.
The AI features 100 levels of difficulties, labeled 1-100.
You can pick either 3D or 2D for your gameplay.
You can also modify your board and chess pieces (just a bit though, like either glass, wood, or marble, etc.)

Overall a simple chess game that's FREE.
Even if you don't think it's a good game due to the negative reviews, it really wouldn't hurt to just play it once to try it out. After all, it IS free.

I really do hate striking down a free product, especially when this is MOSTLY functional...

CONS:

reviewText:
I was so happy to see Chess game on Steam, especially free one. It is nice idea, Steam is great place for Chess to develop even more (in terms of playerbase), especially since many of players here are casual ones. But this game seems laggy (chess, really?!), it has troubles to even load, there are many features missing.. Honestly, takes too much effort to even get started, interface is awful, and I won't even mention ads.. All in all, nice idea, it is bound to be succsessful, if executed in the right manner, so I really hope devs will refine this whole thing and make chess popular on Steam (from the looks of it, they are really trying to work out all of our suggestions so props to them!), but as of now, I would skip it, wait for couple of updates, cause simply put, there are a lot of free chess websites out there that offer more pleasant and more detailed chess experience.

I remain hopeful this will get updated and reworked into great game in the near future!

PS- I really like the amount of AI difficulty levels; great thing for brining new players in!

reviewText:
Three Words.

Steam. Multiplayer. Chess.

Finally, a decent chess game is on Steam, and to top it off its Free to Play! Plays great so far, with only a few minimal bugs/crashes, but the developers are working as quickly as they can to improve the game/add suggestions.  There is an Upgrade to Premium option for $5.00 which removes ads, but I have really only seen ads in Single Player play against the CPU. Online Play hasn't giving me ads yet.

Its been really fun playing against other Steam users in the past few games I've played. This is a welcome treat to Steam.  Looks like this is the closest we will get to having the old Steam Parlor games from the olden days of Steam. Now all we need is a Checkers game and maybe Tic Tac Toe!

Really nice chess game, looking forward to the many improvements to come! A Must Play game for any Steam user who likes Chess.

Can't rotate the board around, and couldn't find a way to put the letters and numbers of the columns on. There were keyboard shortcuts, but no way to input your move via keyboard.

All in all, perhaps better than other chess games, but I don't like it all that much.

reviewText:
Well, I am a chess player with 1700 elo rating and I enjoy to go chess tournaments etc. but i tested this game like an hour and i can say its worst experience i have ever done about chess! Let me explain why:
1. Online mode's timer
Online mode have timer yes, but its completely useless since timing choices going like 1 min/per move and 10 min/per move, why didnt you put 2 min 3 min etc. too? Come on, 10 min/per move match lasts 9 times more than 1 min/per move its an abyss.
Worse than that, you cant see your timer whilst playing in-game! You need to get some telephone timer and check, its stupid af.
Also this game doesnt have fischer timer clock which is extremely stupid too, maybe I want to play like just 5-45 min short match and by game's system its impossible, because you can wait 1 min for every move, so even if you playing with shortest time mode game might be take 2 hours.
I noticed that you cant use timer while playing with AI.
2. AI system
I used stockfish to develop for chess tournaments, and I know that its strong af, but come on I am 1700 elo player and I doubt if level 10 AI did mistake while playing with me, game finished draw and then I played once more time, at that game he made an obvious mistake, and I won easily, I am trying to say that its unbalanced and even can level 10 AI go crazy sometimes.
3. Music
I am %100 sure that I heard main music on another game at Kongregate, I am not trying to say gamemakers stole that but they could have used some original music for game.
In-game musics are also stupid, I know I can mute that but it had negative effect when I played for first time.
4. Boards
Even Chessmaster(which is an old game) have some cool graphics and boards, but this game not very much board option, bad graphics and you have to check them by playing a game(no inspect mode).
I have noticed that much thing in only 1 hour, this game is really awkward trust me.
